reviews.review_msg:
2 big group projects. 4 more projects. 11 assignments. 2 quizzes. A LOT of presentations, which take time away from learning.

Terrible at teaching. Reads off slides. Dense, incoherent slides. Rude to students. Somewhat generous with grades.

Assignments are useful + difficult, but worth only 2.5% each. Labs where the TAs explain stuff is useful.

The assignment grading system is frustratingly opaque. I've followed requirements and gotten same inputs/outputs, yet lost marks without clear feedback. Hard to learn from mistakes when I don't know what they are. A more transparent system would help.
Inconsistent grading criteria. Avoid him since there are many alternative profs available for this course.
His slides are erroneous.

Terrible quizzes. Terrible mistake-riddle slides. 

Won't learn anything in his class.

His class is him just readiing his mistake ridden slides. 

Additionally, there is a noticeable inconsistency in the grading criteria, which undergoes frequent changes on a weekly basis. 

Moreover, his teaching abilities are wanting, marked by challenges in both the articulation of the English language and logical comprehension
Great professor, terrible quizzes. If you read the slides and practice outside of your own time, you'll do just fine.

I really enjoyed his CMPT 120 class (it was my first time coding). His slides were easy to understand and follow. He did gave some challenging homework tasks, but the midterm and final exams were fairly easy to score in. I enjoyed this course so much that I decided to change my major!

He's such a kind and caring guy. The lectures weren't very understandable and sometimes legit useless, but the detailed slides make up for it. He's inexperienced with teaching, but I think you should give him a chance, he really tried his absolute best to teach. Assignments/exams were easy & fair (I had some previous programming knowledge though).
All i'm going to say is that he cares more about the class average than actual students learning experiences.

I had prior coding experience and did not need to learn too much new information. However, once I had a question and approached to ask wasn't helpful and it seemed he had limited knowledge especially if you ask out of scope questions. Other students struggled to keep up with the course pace. Generally, I recommend looking for alternative profs.

had zero coding experience and despite this course being an intro level, i really struggled. he ran a very fast paced course with heavy and difficult assignments that a lot of people struggled on BUT hes a super nice guy and really encourages attending office hours or emailing him. he's helpful and really wants everyone to succeed

Poor teaching skills and messy slides. Seemed approachable and organized at the begging of the semester so no one drop the course and afterwards he was kinda rude with monotonic and boring tone and unfair expectations. Just avoid. You learn nothing.

He is one of the nicest instructors I've ever had. He answers questions quickly on Piazza. Many complained about the difficulty of quizzes, but they were definitely doable. They were all online open book too and were only worth 10% of the course. He prepared practice exams for the midterm and final, both similar difficulties to the actual exams.

I'd say with having absolutely no prior coding experience, I found Mohammad to be pretty decent at teaching the subject. However, lectures can be boring, but can't really blame the guy since compsci is boring. He is super nice and caring only thing I would say is that assignments are a bit tricky and gradescope makes the experience even worse.

Coming from someone who's doing well in his class, avoid him (for 120 at least). He is very caring, did try his best, and gave reasonable exams, but his boring and convoluted lectures plus brutal assignments made CMPT 120 extremely painful. If you've never programmed before, good luck, because his expectations are insane for an intro course.

Great professor overall, is really caring towards his students and encourages everyone to succeed. Assignments are pretty tough but he is very helpful if you go to his office hours, and his lectures are also super useful. Final exam was pretty tough but fair, just make sure to keep up with topics and practice often!

Super nice guy and truly cares about his students. Gave multiple extensions on assignments. His exams are fair and the assignments prepare you for the exam. Provides tons of resources and practice questions, and makes an effort to get to know his students.

Prof Tayebi is a really good guy. As a first time coder, assignments were difficult but he was understanding and gave extensions. Exams were easier and are similar to his practise exams. He is really nice, tries to get to know his students, and wants to make sure students learn something and can apply it.

The class was very hard but he was a very caring prof and truly wanted his students to succeed. If you want to do well in this course with him you WILL have to actually put in the time and effort. He was very forgiving and gave extensions. Assignments are made extremely hard implementing everything we learned making the exams easier.

his exams are fair. he provides practice exams that prepare you well enough for the exams. he gave extensions to his assignments, but I feel like he wouldn't need to do that if he made the assignments a little easier. workload can be a lot if you have other classes to prioritize, other than that, he's a pretty good prof.

His assignments and quizzes are really hard, but the midterm and the final were quite fair tbh. He was really responsive and helpful if you asked. There was a free textbook but i feel lectures were better to work from as his slides are informative. Nice guy, gave lots of talks about life.

His assignments are really hard but as long as you put in the work it's possible to get 100 on a majority of them. He truly loves teaching but I think he fails to realize how difficult his assignments especially for people with no coding experience. His midterms are a breeze as long as you understand the fundamentals and review the quizzes

Honestly speaking, he's not as bad as these reviews make him out to be. He's obviously knowledgeable in the topics he's teaching and passionate about his job. He just doesn't know how to relay information well especially to first time coders. His assignments and quizzes are difficult but his exams aren't actually too bad if you studied well.
lack of enough knowledge and a low-level and disrespectful personality in interactions.

His philosophies in teaching are respectable but he is not a fitting instructor for CMPT 120. 
Lecture slides contain mistakes, convoluted explanations, unreasonable quizzes, and you're thrown into the fire with homework. If I'm struggling despite having prior coding experience, then I don't know how first-time programmers can survive his course.

His class is not helpful at all. For someone who has no coding experience, this class will make you stress, and it's a waste of time. The assignment is extremely hard than what he teaches in the lecture. You need to learn extra from different website to understand. Overall not worth it for someone who is beginner in coding.

I don't think his teaching style is suitable for lower level classes. His expectations are too high and he does not go over the examples enough for us to comprehend them. Quizzes worded very weirdly at first but it's improved. The assignments seem too complex for it to be intro level but it is possible to get 100 if you work on it enough.

He refuses to give partial marks for anything because "nobody wants half-working code", which is terrible for anybody who has no coding experience, and wants to try it out. Rushes through material, he's gone through about 3/4 of all of the python programming language in a month and a half. Super rude and condescending in his responses to questions.

Assignments are unnecessarily long and tougher than they should be, lectures are dry and not really helpful just read the slides. He was interactive and enthusiastic during the first 2 weeks of class and afterwards he became monotoned and extremely boring causing almost everyone to zone out.

Slides have a lot of mistakes and quizzes are hard. Assignments are tough and even more hard with an autograder. Lectures are confusing and boring. Really frustrating and not beginner friendly like the course says it is

Like the comment below said, the assignment grading system is super frustrating and doesn't let you know where the error is. You could do everything that was asked for in the assignment with identical input/outputs but still get marks deducted.
when people say he has poor english or whatever it's not true. his slides are difficult to follow but it is not due to his language skills

As someone with no coding experience whatsoever, I am struggling in this class as of right now...even though the course description made it sound like it was suitable for me. I do recall the prof saying he was rushing through the basics to give us more time to do other stuff or something like that? And it is NOT working. Take it with someone else.

Lectures are difficult to follow. Professor makes an already difficult topic even worse. His explanations are difficult to understand as he overcomplicates things, and is quite condescending with answers to questions. Goes through the material extremely quickly, and adds unnecessary exploratory topics to the lecture that are not helpful.

Doesn't know how to teach first year courses. He is poorly prepared for lectures, his slides are a mess, the questions/examples are full of errors. He does not teach the material in a clear/approachable way for beginners. The assignment grading system is frustrating and the quizzes are impossible and often include things not covered yet in class.

Super nice and well organized. Always happy to help students by all means. Assignments were relevant to the course material. The course was offered online and he handled it well. Exams were very fair and he did not seem to be tough grader. I do recommend him for this course

OMG! this prof screwed the grades at the end of the semester. obviously, people getting A,A+ would say good things but I am really disappointed that in a cmpt course at 87% I got B. and explain me how is this a higher grade for my hard work? this means people who get in range of A are the respectable ones only.

The course was well organized by Prof. Tayebi and we got good feedback from the assignments which really helped us in the group project. The final was a bit scuffed but everything else I think was well done. He is easily accessible through Piazza and will answer most if not all questions in a timely manor. Would recommend.

I understand sql stuff are relatively easy to teach in CS, but still, he's one of the best CMPT professor I've had so far. He is extremely organized and the amount of resources he gives is really appreciated. His TA management is great as well. He can sometimes be a little hard to understand, but overall I've had an amazing experience in this class

Had lots of learning resources that helped me learn/practice concepts (lectures, tutorials, mentorships, practicals, Ripple, Piazza) but only Ripple questions were for marks/mandatory. Homework and exam were exactly what I expected but obviously harder than usual but still doable. I recommend doing the practicals, they really help

His lectures are good but he is really a tough grader if the class average is high. I dont mind whatever grade scheme is being used in his class but he should specify in the starting that he is going to screw your GPA with his own decided grade scheme. I am really disappointed at the end of the semester and I am sad that I took my classes with him

Solid lecture notes, lectures themselves can run late sometimes but content is good. Semester projects and homework assignments were solid and helped you apply material learned in class well. Easy to reach and get feedback outside of class, and was flexible in adjusting assignments/projects according to student feedback. Solid prof, would take.
